title: <italic>NUDT21</italic>-spanning CNVs lead to neuropsychiatric disease and altered MeCP2 abundance via alternative polyadenylation
abstract: The brain is sensitive to the dose of MeCP2 such that small fluctuations in protein quantity lead to neuropsychiatric disease. Despite the importance of MeCP2 levels to brain function, little is known about its regulation. In this study, we report eleven individuals with neuropsychiatric disease and copy-number variations spanning <italic>NUDT21</italic>, which encodes a subunit of pre-mRNA cleavage factor Im. Investigations of <italic>MECP2</italic> mRNA and protein abundance in patient-derived lymphoblastoid cells from one <italic>NUDT21</italic> deletion and three duplication cases show that <italic>NUDT21</italic> regulates MeCP2 protein quantity. Elevated <italic>NUDT21</italic> increases usage of the distal polyadenylation site in the <italic>MECP2</italic> 3â€² UTR, resulting in an enrichment of inefficiently translated long mRNA isoforms. Furthermore, normalization of <italic>NUDT21</italic> via siRNA-mediated knockdown in duplication patient lymphoblasts restores MeCP2 to normal levels. Ultimately, we identify <italic>NUDT21</italic> as a novel candidate for intellectual disability and neuropsychiatric disease, and elucidate a mechanism of pathogenesis by MeCP2 dysregulation via altered alternative polyadenylation.
